text: hi this is FEMA and I am back with a new
lesson on nouns with different meanings
when they are used in the singular and
the plural form well this is a very
interesting lesson because a lot of
nouns used in the singular and the
plural form mean totally different
things
so what are they the first pair of nouns
are the word air and it's pool form
which is airs well what is air when I
say air I'm talking about the oxygen and
other gases that we breathe so I could
say that we need air to breathe human
beings need air to breathe that's what
air means when it is used in the
singular form but what does the word
airs mean when I put that in the pure
form it means being very proud or being
really uptight or to put it very simply
it means thinking too much of yourself
so I could say that the Queen always
puts on airs when she addresses the
crowd that basically means that you
think you are
higher or over everybody else our next
pair of nouns which mean totally
different are the words blind and its
full form which is called blinds well
what is the word blind mean blind refers
to a person without sight or someone who
cannot see so I can say that I helped
the blind man cross the road that's what
the word blind refers to but when I
and s and make it a plural word what is
the word blinds mean blinds means the
rolling shutters of a window we all have
that at home don't we so your mom could
say you know it's very sunny outside put
the blinds which means that you roll the
shutters it's like rolling shutters
against your window pane which kind of
you know lets the light out or keeps the
Sun away so that's the difference
between the word blind and blinds our
next pair of nouns is the word character
and it's plural form which is characters
now what is character mean when I say I
have a very good character or you need
to develop a very good character I'm
talking about your traits your
personality or can I say your personal
qualities so I could talk about being
honest I could talk about being very
very quick or being very very good or
very nice or very kind they all refer to
personal qualities as opposed to that
when I add an S against the same word
making it a plural form characters would
mean alphabets or letters I can say that
we couldn't understand the characters
because it was written in Mandarin or
Spanish or any other language that we
don't understand so that's the
difference between characters and
character our next pair of words is
custom and the word customs when I have
a custom which is in a singular form I
am referring to a social practice
back here in India we have a social
custom of maybe you know worshipping
idols some of us do so that's a social
custom it is a social practice that
people do out of religious reasons but
when I add an S to the end of the custom
I'm talking about in boat duty so I
could say that my friend is a customs
officer which means that he is in charge
of all the work at his place that refers
to everything related to import duty so
that's the difference between the word
custom and customs moving on to our next
pair of nouns is the word content as
opposed to content when I use that in
the plural form what is the meaning of
the word content content means extremely
happy extremely satisfied so I can say
that I am very content because I came
from a very good vacation or I'm very
content because I have done very well in
school today so that's the state of
being fully satisfied fully happy and
when you have contents with the s after
the content the plural form basically
indicates the things that are contained
in something
so suppose you have a box okay and
you've got you know a watch you have a
few things in it the things contained in
the box
refers to condense all right so that's
the difference between the word content
and content I'll be back with some more
words on the nouns with different
meanings all right moving on to our next
pair of nouns with different meanings we
have the word good and the word goods so
when I have a word good in the singular
form I'm talking about having a benefit
so I could say that it is good for you
to exercise it is good for you to eat
healthy which means that you are doing
something for the good or for your
benefit as opposed to that you have the
word good with it with an S which means
that it is a pure form called goods
meaning articles or simply things that
you purchase so in most shops it is
always mentioned that the goods once one
sold cannot be exchanged or goods that
are sold can be exchanged only within
seven working days of buying them so
goods refers to articles anything that
you purchase now we have the extra force
and the word forces in the plural form
when I use the force in the singular I'm
talking about strength now it could be
our physical strength or it could be
mental strength that is the strength of
the mind so I could or in natural
strength when it talks about the
strength of you know the nature
so I could say that the force of the
wind was so much that everything flew so
its strength that we refer to when I use
the word force as against as opposed to
that you have forces which talk about
the army so I can say that our defense
forces are very strong so I'm referring
to the army it could be your national
army your defence army or whatever you
want to call it and then you have the
world spectacle in the singular against
the word spectacles in the plural
what does spectacle mean spectacle means
nothing but a sight all right I can say
that it was a horrible spectacle to see
the car topple over so I'm talking about
a sight it could be a good sight a very
bad sight on the other hand when I use
the word spectacles in the plural form
I'm talking about glasses that we wear I
could say that my spectacles are too big
for my face or you need to wear you know
nice spectacles so we're talking about
glasses that we wear for our eyes now
our next expression is the word would
against the world woods well what is the
word would in its singular form mean
would refers to nothing as timber so
wood is nothing but a particular type of
timber this white boat out here is made
up of a particular form of timber I
could say that the bookshelf
is made up of teak wood it is a
particular form of wood or timber on the
other hand when I refer to the word
woods I'm talking about a small jungle
you know with lots of trees and shrubs
and things growing out there so I can
say that the young couple went for a
stroll in the woods so they went out for
walk in the woods which is a really a
small jungle and our last pair of nouns
with different meanings include the word
manor along with its port form which is
manners when I talk about manner in the
singular form I'm talking about a style
or shall I say a method it's a style or
a method of doing something so I can say
that there is a manner of doing your
work in an organized way there is a
manner of solving your your your math
problem in a much better way it's it is
a style or a method of doing something
but when I have the word manners in its
plural form I'm referring to social
behavior or the social norm as we call
it so I can say that it is very bad
manners to speak with your food in your
mouth
so that it refers to everything that
talks about social behavior social
manners or social etiquette so that's it
from this lesson on nouns with different
meanings
I hope you've understood and found it
very interesting well I'll be back with
some more lessons until then this is me
saying goodbye
